member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.AltitudeMeasurement
member.summary: Represents a altitude measurement and display.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, altitude measurements have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of meters. An application can take an altitude value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the altitude value must be converted to meters to be stored in HealthVault.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Measurement`1
member.summary: Represents a length value and display. This class is abstract.
member.remarks: HealthVault measurements are composed of the value and a display value. All values are stored in a base unit for that type of measurement. An application can take a value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user- entered value as the display value, but the measurement value must be converted to the appropriate base unit to be stored in HealthVault. This abstract base class defines an interface from which all measurements derive. The property's type varies according to the derived class definition and affects the base unit for that type. See the documentation for the derived class for more information on the base unit type for that measurement.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Measurement`1.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Measurement class with no value.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Measurement`1.#ctor(`0)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Measurement class with the specified value.
member.param: An instance of MeasurementType representing the value.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Measurement`1.#ctor(`0,Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.DisplayValue)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Measurement class with the specified value and optional display value.
member.param: An instance of MeasurementType representing the value.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ApproximateTime.HasValue
member.summary: Gets a boolean indicating whether this ApproximateTime has a value in it.
member.returns: True if there is a value.
member.remarks: ApproximateTime instances are initialized into state without a value, but the Hour and Minute properties must still return numbers in that case. member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the assessed area.

member.summary: Gets or sets the calculated value of the assessed area.
member.remarks: The value may be coded using a specific set of values. Example: Low/Medium/High risk. A list of vocabularies may be found in the preferred vocabulary "health-assessment-value-sets". Contact the HealthVault team to help define the preferred vocabulary.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Assessment.Group
member.summary: Gets or sets the additional information that can be used to help organize the results.
member.remarks: The group is used to specify which group a specific result is in. For example, the supporting assessments that follow a main assessment are coded to indicate that they are supporting by specifying the "supporting" code. The preferred vocabulary for route is "health-assessment-groups". Contact the HealthVault team to help define the preferred vocabulary.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.AsthmaInhaler
member.summary: Represents a health record item that encapsulates an asthma inhaler.
member.remarks: This class can represent any inhaler unit used to treat asthma. The inhaler may or may not have a device component to it. Each new canister should be represented by a new instance, even if there is a containing device that is reusable. Changes in regimen (minimum/maximum doses per day) should also cause a new health record item to be created.

members.member:
Gets or sets the target of the inhaler usage.
A instance representing the dosage purpose.
Examples include relief (the dose purpose is intended to relieve immediate asthma symptoms), prevention (the dose purpose is intended to prevent asthma symptoms), control (the dose purpose is intended to control the impact of current asthma symptoms), other (the dose purpose is known, but other than to relieve, prevent or control asthma symptoms), and undefined (there is not enough information about the inhaler usage to discern purpose).
Codes for this value are in the "dose-purpose" vocabulary.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.BloodGlucoseMeasurement
member.summary: Represents a blood glucose measurement.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, blood glucose readings have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of mmol/L. An application can take a blood glucose value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the blood glucose value must be converted to mmol/L to be stored in HealthVault.

The display value of the blood glucose measurement. This should contain the exact measurement as entered by the user, even if it uses some other unit of measure besides mmol/L. The display value and
represents the unit of measure for the user-entered value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.DisplayValue
member.summary: Represents the display value for a length, weight, or other type of measurement.
member.remarks:
A display value differs from a value in that it is the value as entered by the user rather than the value converted to a base unit. The unit used can also reference the unit through the HealthVault dictionary code.
Single-valued display values ("15 pounds") should be expressed using the and properties.
Multi-valued display values ("12 pounds 3 ounces") can be expressed using the property, but should also be expressed using value and units ("12.25 pounds").

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with empty values.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified value.
member.param: The value as it was entered.

member.param: The value as it was entered.

Distances are stored in meters. The application must convert the distance entered by the user into meters and should also store the distance and units entered by the user in the display-value so that it can be displayed to the user in their preferred unit of measure when viewing the data.
Set the value to null if there is no distance.

member.summary: Detail name for LeftRightBalance_percent.
member.remarks: This detail stores the balance between the left and right leg when cycling, and is a number from 0 to 1. The detail stores the percentage of work the left leg is performing, and the right leg percentage is 1 minus the left leg value. For example, if the this value is 0.45, the left leg is doing 45% of the work and the right leg is doing 55% of the work.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSamples
member.summary: Stores a set of samples related to an exercise.
member.remarks:
Examples: Heart rate samples, speed samples, position samples.
Exercise samples are related to exercises through related items.
The samples are stored in the other-data section of the object, and must be fetched by specifying HealthItemRecordSections.BlobPayload.
The format of the other-data section is the HealthVault comma-separated format. It should be accessed using the ExerciseSamplesData property.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSamples.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the kind of information that is stored in this sample set.
member.remarks:
The name encodes both the type of information that is stored and the units in which it is stored.
The preferred vocabulary is exercise-sample-names.
Example sample types and units. See the preferred vocabulary for others. Heartrate_BPM Distance_meters Position_LatLong Speed_m-per-s Pace_s-per-100m Power_watts Torque_Nm Cadence_RPM Temperature_celsius Altitude_meters AirPressure_kPa Steps_count AerobicSteps_count

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSamples.Unit
member.summary: Gets or sets the unit of measure for the samples.
member.remarks:
The preferred vocabulary is exercise-units.
The appropriate units are defined by the code used for the Name property. For example, if the name property is set to the entry Power_watts, the Unit should be coded to watts.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSamples.SamplingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the initial sampling interval between samples, in seconds.
The samples data format supports modifying the sampling interval in the middle of a set of samples. See the class for more information.
member.returns: An double representing the sampling interval in seconds.
member.exception: If the parameter is less than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSamples.ExerciseSamplesData
member.summary: The sample data.
member.remarks:
The sample data is exposed as a instance.
To get the sample data when fetching an instance of the ExerciseSamples thing type, you must specify that the other-data section be returned to access the ExerciseSamplesData.
member.exception: If the sampling interval has not be set before the property is referenced.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSamplesData
member.summary: The ExerciseSamplesData class is used to store and retrieve samples data for the class. It handles converting from a sample data format to the comma-separated format.
member.remarks:
Data is represented as either an array of samples with a single value (such as heart rate), or an array of samples with two values (such as a GPS position). The or properties should be used as appropriate based on the stored data type.
The underlying format allows the sampling interval to be changed in the middle of a sample set. This class will detect sampling intervals that have changed, and insert appropriate escape values into the resulting data.

member.summary: Gets or sets the type of activity for this segment of the exercise.
member.remarks: Examples: Running, hiking, walking, golfing, dancing. The preferred vocabulary for route is "exercise-activities".

member.summary: Gets or sets a descriptive title for this segment.
member.remarks: Examples: Lap 1, bicycle leg, first half.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSegment.Distance
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance covered in the segment.
member.remarks:
Distances are stored in meters. The application must convert the distance entered by the user into meters and should also store the distance and units entered by the user in the display-value so that it can be displayed to the user in their preferred unit of measure when viewing the data.
Set the value to null if there is no distance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSegment.Duration
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration of the segment in minutes.
member.remarks: Set the value to null if there is no duration.
member.exception: The parameter is negative or zero when set.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSegment.Offset
member.summary: Gets or sets the offset in minutes of the segment from the start of exercise.
member.remarks: Set the value to null if there is no offset.
member.exception: The parameter is negative or zero when set.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.ExerciseSegment.Details
member.summary: Gets additional information about the segment.
member.remarks: Details is a dictionary of the items, where the key is the string name of the item.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.FamilyHistoryV3
member.summary: The condition of a relative.
member.remarks:
The family history condition item stores a condition that a relative of the record-owner has.
To create a family tree, use the relationship-types vocabulary to code both directions of the parent/child relationship between one family member and another. These codes are stored as related items for both parent and child data instances.
The flexibity of having both condition and relative be optional allows applications to give the users the ability to just put in the details they know at the time they want to create the tree. If they just know the name of the relative, or a particular condition that's all it takes to get a new instance started.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.FlowMeasurement
member.summary: Represents a flow of gas, liquid, etc. over time and a display value associated with the measurement.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, flow measurements have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of liters per second (L/s). An application can take a flow value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the flow value must be converted to L/s to be stored in HealthVault.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.GeneticSnpResults
member.summary: Stores a set of SNP genetic test results.
member.remarks:
Examples:
The SNP data is stored in the blob store of the object, and must be fetched by specifying HealthItemRecordSections.BlobPayload.
The format of the other-data section is the HealthVault comma-separated format.
Within the comma-separated data, each SNP is encoded as follows:
[refSNP id],[strand orientation],[result],[assay id],[start position],[end position]
Where: refSNP id: Reference SNP identifier from NCBI dbSNP database. strand orientation: "+" encodes top, "-" encodes bottom. result: the result of the test. assay id: platform dependent probe set id. start position: start position on the chromosome. end posiition: end position on the chromosome.
Example: rs1891906,-,GT, SNP_C-315533, 940106, 940107

member.summary: Creates an instance of with default values.

member.summary: Creates an instance of with specified parameters.
member.param: The date and time of the SNP test.
The genome build that defines the SNPs.
The chromosome on which the SNPs are located.
The numbering scheme used for positions.
member.exception: If or is null or empty, or is not 0 or 1.
The is neither zero based scheme nor one based scheme.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.InsulinInjectionMeasurement
member.summary: Represents an insulin injection measurement.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, insulin injection readings have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of IE. An application can take an insulin injection value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the insulin injection value must be converted to IE to be stored in HealthVault.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.LabTestResultDetails.Status

member.remarks: Examples of status include complete and pending. It should be set to null if it is unknown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.LabTestResultDetails.Note
member.summary: Gets or sets a note that augments the laboratory result.
member.remarks:
There are two scenarios in which a note is typically added: A note may provide additional information about interpreting the result beyond what is stored in the ranges associated with the value. Or, a note may be use to provide the textual result of a lab test that does not have a measured value.
Formatting: Notes may come from systems that require a line-based approach to textual display. To support this, applications should render the spaces and newlines in the note, and use a fixed-width font. The form transform for the lab test results type shows one way to do this.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Length
member.summary: Represents a length value and display.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, lengths have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of meters. An application can take a length value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the length value must be converted to meters to be stored in HealthVault.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with empty values.

member.param: The length in meters.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified value in meters and optional display value.
member.param: The length in meters.

The display value of the length. This should contain the exact length as entered by the user even if it uses some other unit of measure besides meters. The display value and
represents the unit of measure for the user-entered value.

member.summary: Verifies that the value is a legal length value in meters.
member.param: The length measurement.
member.exception: The parameter is less than or equal to zero.

member.summary: Writes the length to the specified XML writer.
member.param: The XmlWriter to write the length to.

member.summary: Gets a string representation of the length in the base units.
member.returns: The length as a string in the base units.

member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the length in meters.
member.remarks: The value must be in meters. The can be used to store the user-entered value in a scale other than metric.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.MedicalImageStudy
member.summary: Represents a health record item type that encapsulates a study containing medical images.
member.remarks:
DICOM data is stored in the named BLOB portion of the data type, and it is recommended that normal DICOM conventions are used for naming.
An application may store XDS-i manifest information in XML format in the xds-i element.

member.summary: Gets or sets the reason for the study.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.MedicalImageStudy.PreviewBlobName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the BLOB holding a smaller version of the image suitable for web viewing or email.
member.remarks: If there is no preview BLOB name the value should be set to null. Previews should be stored using the jpeg or png format. It is recommended that the shorter dimension of the image be no less than 500 pixels in size.

member.summary: Gets the important images in the study.
member.remarks: If there is no information about the key images the collection should be empty.

member.summary: Gets or sets the study instance UID.
member.remarks: This value corresponds to DICOM tag (0020,000D). If there is no study instance UID the value should be set to null.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message
member.summary: The Message type is used to store a multipart mail message, including message text and attachments.
member.remarks:
The message is stored in two forms. The "FullMessage" blob contains the message in the native format. The text of the message is available in the blobs denoted by the 'html-blob-name" and "text-blob-name" element. Any attachments to the message are described in the "attachments" element.
The data stored is intended to be compatible with the SendMail Multipart MIME format.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with default values.
member.remarks: This item is not added to the health record until the method is called.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class specifying mandatory values.
member.remarks: This item is not added to the health record until the method is called.
member.param: The date and time of the message.
The size of the message in bytes.

member.summary: Retrieves the unique identifier for this type.

member.summary: Populates the instance from the data in the specified XML.
member.param: The XML to get the Message data from.
member.exception: If the first node in is not a Message node.

member.summary: Writes the XML representation of the Message into the specified XML writer.
member.param: The XML writer into which the Message should be written.

member.summary: Gets a string representation of the Message.
member.returns: A string representation of the Message.

member.summary: Gets or sets the date and time of the message.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.Headers
member.summary: Gets the header information associated with this message.
member.remarks: The header information is stored in a dictionary of collections. For example, Headers["To"] returns the collection of all the "To" headers in the message, or null if there were not such headers associated with the message.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the message in bytes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.Summary
member.summary: Gets or sets a summary of the message.
member.remarks: The summary contains the first 512 characters of the message in text format. This information is used to display the start of the message without having to fetch the blobs that store the whole message.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.HtmlBlobName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the blob that stores the message in HTML format.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.TextBlobName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the blob that stores the message in text format.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.Subject
member.summary: Gets or sets the subject of the message.
member.remarks:
The Subject property is equivalent to Headers["Subject"].
The value of the property is null if there is no subject in the header collection.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.From
member.summary: Gets or sets the origin of the message.
member.remarks:
The From property is equivalent to Headers["From"].
The value of the property is null if there is no from in the header collection.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.Message.Attachments
member.summary: Gets the collection of attachments to the message.
member.remarks: If there are no attachments the collection will be empty.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.PaceMeasurement
member.summary: Represents a pace measurement and display.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, pace measurements have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of seconds per 100 meters. An application can take a pace value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the pace value must be converted to seconds per 100 meters to be stored in HealthVault.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified value in seconds per 100 meters and optional display value.
member.param: The pace in seconds per 100 meters.

The display value of the pace. This should contain the exact pace as entered by the user even if it uses some other unit of measure besides seconds per 100 meters. The display value and
represents the unit of measure for the user-entered value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.PowerMeasurement
member.summary: Represents a power measurement and display.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, power measurements have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of watts. An application can take a pace value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the power value must be converted to watts to be stored in HealthVault.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified value in watts and optional display value.
member.param: The power in watts.

The display value of the power. This should contain the exact power as entered by the user even if it uses some other unit of measure besides watts. The display value and
represents the unit of measure for the user-entered value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.PressureMeasurement
member.summary: Represents a pressure measurement and a display value associated with the measurement.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, pressure measurements have values and display values. All values are stored in a standard SI unit of pascal (Pa). An application can take a pressure value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the pressure value must be converted to pascals to be stored in HealthVault.

The display value of the pressure. This should contain the exact pressure as entered by the user even if it uses some other unit of measure besides pascal. The display value and
represents the unit of measure for the user-entered value.

member.summary: Writes the SNP Items to the specified XmlWriter.

member.summary: Take the dictionary SNP items, and convert them into the underlying format.

member.summary: Gets the SNP data as a dictionary of SNP items.
member.remarks: SNP items in a dictionary can be easily accessed by the reference SNP Id.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.SnpItem
member.summary: A SNP test result item.
member.remarks:
Within the comma-separated data, each SNP is encoded as follows:
[refSNP id],[strand orientation],[result],[assay id],[start position],[end position]
Where: refSNP id: Reference SNP identifier from NCBI dbSNP database. strand orientation: "+" encodes top, "-" encodes bottom. result: the result of the test. assay id: Platform dependent probe set id. start position: Start position on the chromosome. end position: End position on the chromosome.
Example: rs1891906,-,GT, SNP_C-315533, 940106, 940107

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.SnpItem.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an instance of the type with default values.

member.summary: Creates an instance of the type with the specified values.
member.param: Reference SNP Id (rs).
The orientation of the strand.
The result of the SNP test.
The platform dependent probe set id.
The start position on the chromosome.
The end position on the chromosome.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.SnpItem.ToString
member.summary: Gets a string representation of the snp result item.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.SnpItem.ReferenceSnpId
member.summary: Gets or sets the Reference SNP ID of the result.
member.remarks: For example, rs132342.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.SnpItem.StrandOrientation
member.summary: Gets or sets the orientation of the strand.
member.remarks: The value can be either + or -.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.SnpItem.Result
member.summary: Gets or sets the result of the SNP test.
member.remarks: For example, AA, AT. Each letter correspond to one copy of the specified SNP is the customer's genome, since each of us has two copies of each gene under normal circumstance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.SnpItem.AssayId
member.summary: Gets or sets the assay ID.

member.remarks: In HealthVault, speed measurements have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of meters per second (m/s). member.summary: Populates this instance from the data in the XML.
member.param: The XML to get the test result range data from.

member.summary: Writes the test result range data to the specified XmlWriter.
member.param: The name of the node to write XML.
The XmlWriter to write the test result range data to.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.TestResultRange.ToString
member.summary: Gets a string representation of the test result range item.
member.returns: A string representation of the test result range item.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.TestResultRange.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum and maximum of the range.
member.remarks: The minimum or maximum value may be omitted to specify open-ended ranges. Example: The range "greater than 3.5" would be coded by setting the minimum to 3.5 and omitting the maximum.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.TestResultRange.RangeType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of the range.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.TestResultRange.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the range expressed as text.
member.remarks:
The text element is used in two different ways: When a numeric range is used, the text element should contain a textual version of the numeric range. When the range is non-numeric, the text element contains the range and the range value is omitted. The range may also be coded to a vocabulary.
Examples: A color range (such as clear to yellow) would be coded using by setting the text element to "clear to yellow", and by assigning a code from an appropriate vocabulary.
A numeric range (such as 0.5 - 1.6) would be stored in the minimum and maximum elements of the value, and \ additionally would be coded by setting the text element to "0.5 - 1.6".
Contact the HealthVault team to help define this vocabulary.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.TestResultRangeValue
member.summary: Represents a lab test result range value.
member.remarks:
A range consists of minimum and/or maximum values. An open-ended range may be created by omitting the minimum or maximum value.
For example, "greater than 3.5" is created by setting the minimum value to 3.5 and the maximum value to null.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.VolumeMeasurement
member.summary: Represents the volume of a gas, liquid, etc. and a display value associated with the measurement.
member.remarks: In HealthVault, volume measurements have values and display values. All values are stored in a base unit of liters (L). An application can take a volume value using any scale the application chooses and can store the user-entered value as the display value, but the volumn value must be converted to liters to be stored in HealthVault.
